div.l: To grinde oure corn̄ and cary it hame ageyn̄
I pray you spede us henne als syne as ye may
It shalbe do coth Symkin if that I may
What wil ye do whils it is in hand
Be god riȝt by the hopir wil I stand
Coth Iohn / and se hough the corn̄ gase in
Yit saugh I neuer be my fadir kynne
Hough that þe hopir waggis to and fro
Aleyn ansuerd Iohn wiltou so
Then wil I be benethe be my croun̄
And se hough the mele fallis a doun̄
Into the trough / that shalbe my disport
For Iohn in faith I may be ene of your͗e sort
I is as ille a Milner as ye
This Milner smylid at her͗e nycite
And thouȝt al this is don̄ but for a wile
They wene that no man may hem begile
But be my thrift yit shal I blere her iȝe
For al the sleight in her philosophie
The mo queint crekis that they make
The more wil I stele whan that I take
In stede of flour yit wil I yeue hem bren̄
The grettist clerkis be not wisist men̄
As whilom the wulf spak to the mare
Of al her art ne count I not a tare
Out of the dore he goth fulle priuily
Whan þat he saugh his time softily
He lokid up and doun til he had found
The clerkis hors where he stood y boıı̄und
Behinde the Mille vndir a leueselle
And to the hors he goth him feire ⁊and well
He stripith of the bridil right anon̄
And whan the hors was louse he gȳynneþ to gon̄
Toward the fenne ther wilde mares renne
And furth with wighee thurgh thic ⁊and thenne
The Milner͗e goth ageyn no wurd he seid
But doth his note and with the clerkis pleid
Til that her corn̄ was feir͗e y ground
And whan the mele was sackid ⁊and y boıı̄und
This Iohn goth out and fint his hors awey
And gan to crye harrou and welawey
Oure hors is lost Aleyn̄ for goddis benys
Steppe on thy fete come of man attenys
